etymology.description: Couvercle with a handle -> false friend: roof of a tower in 高(高) (gāo, "high") -> head and open arms in 立(立) (lì, "stand")/交(交) (jiāo, "exchange") -> roof of a hut in 六(六) (liù, "six") -> top of traditional cloth in 衣(衣) (yī, "clothing") -> mark over silk threads in 玄(玄) (xuán, "mysterious") -> top of knife/chisel to mark prisoners in 辛(辛) (xīn, "bitter") -> grass in 离(离) (lí, "leave")
etymology.interpretation: 亠 is primarily a pictogram that initially represented a cover with a handle. However, its usage varies in different characters, symbolizing roofs, heads, tops of clothing, and marks, showing its flexibility and evolution in form and meaning across contexts.

examples.chinese: 在汉字结构中(在漢字結構中)，亠作为顶标发挥作用(亠作為頂標發揮作用)。
examples.pinyin: Zài hànzì jiégòu zhōng, tóu zuòwéi dǐngbiāo fāhuī zuòyòng.
examples.english: In the structure of Chinese characters, 亠 acts as a top mark to exert its function.

examples.chinese: 古代书法作品中(古代書法作品中)，亠显示出独特的审美价值(亠顯示出獨特的審美價值)。
examples.pinyin: Gǔdài shūfǎ zuòpǐn zhōng, tóu xiǎnshì chū dútè de shěnměi jiàzhí.
examples.english: In ancient calligraphy, 亠 demonstrates a unique aesthetic value.
